module.name: independent_property_definition
module.keywords: module, physical quantity, property, characteristic, value

purpose.P: This application module is concerned with aspects of a physical thing that can be determined by observation or measurement. Observations or measurements can be made of the following physical things.

LI.P: a point within a product at a state;

example.P: Temperature, pressure, density, stress are quantities that can be measured at a point within a product at a state.
This is of course an idealisation. It is not possible to measure the temperature at a point for a state, because a temperature sensor has a finite size and a finite thermal capacity.

LI.P: a part or feature of a product at a state;

example.P: Area and axial force are quantities that can be measured at a cross section of a beam at a state.

Thickness and bending moment (a second order tensor in 2D) and aggregate membrane force (a second order tensor in 2D) are quantities that can be measured at a fibre normal to the plane of a shell at a state.

LI.P: a whole body (or product) at a state;

example.P: Volume, mass and kinetic energy are quantities that can be measured for a whole body at a state.

LI.P: a point within a product for a whole activity;

example.P: Absorbed energy density is a quantity that can be measured at a point for a whole activity.
Number of stress reversals is a quantity that can be measured at a point for a whole activity.

LI.P: a part or feature of a product for a whole activity;

example.P: Total mass of fluid passing through a surface is a quantity that can be measured at a cross section of a duct for a whole activity.

LI.P: a whole body (or product) for a whole activity.

example.P: Total absorbed energy is a quantity that can be measured for a whole body for a whole activity.

LI.p: the nature or magnitude of an observable or measurable aspect;

note.P: This is called an 'independent property definition'. It is a class that an individual product, activity or state can be a member of.

example.P: The temperature of 400 degrees Celsius is an independent property definition. The widget with serial number 1234 at 10:30 on 1998-11-05 is a member of this class.

note.P: A class of property is a class that an independent property definition can be a member of. A class of property can indicate the nature of the physical phenomenon that is observed or measured, or the symmetry with respect to orientation.

example.P: Temperature is a class of property. The independent property definition that is the temperature of 400 degrees Celsius is a member of this class.
Isotropic is a class of property. The independent property definition that is the elasticity with Young's modulus of 210000 MN m -2 and Poisson's ratio of 0.3 is a member of this class.

LI.P: the distinction between a point property definition and a range property definition;

example.P: 400 degrees Kelvin is a point property definition. 400 to 410 degrees Kelvin is a range property definition.

The statement that a thing has a temperature of 400 degrees Kelvin is almost certainly a loose statement with an implied tolerance. The statement that a thing has a temperature within the range 400 to 410 degress Kelvin is more rigorous.

LI.P: a relationship between an independent property definition and a class of property.

UL.LI: the physical phenomenon for the independent property definition; and
the symmetry for the independent property definition.

outscope.LI: a property distribution over a set of parts or features within a product, or a set of states within an activity;

LI.P: a relationship between an independent property definition and an individual product or activity, or a class of product or activity;

note.P: These relationships are within the scope of the Possession_of_property and Property_condition application modules.

LI.P: a numerical description of an independent property definition with respect to a scale.

note.P: NOTE 4 - The description of the independent property definition 400 degrees Kelvin by the number 400 with respect to the Kelvin scale, is within the scope of the Property_identification application module.

def.p: nature or magnitude of an aspect of a physical thing that can be observed or measured, or deduced from observations or measurements

note.P: An independent property definition is a class that a physical thing is can be a member of. Whether or not a physical thing is a member of the class is determined by the observation or measurement.

The deprecated terms do not have the word 'value', which indicates that a particular value is intended rather than the set or space of all possible values. Hence a term, such as 'physical quantity', does not distinguish between 'temperature' - a space of possible values, and 'the temperature of 20 degrees Celsius' - a particular temperature value.

description.P: The Independent_property_definition UoF specifies whether an independent property definition is:

example.P: The mass of 10 Kg is a point property definition within the mass property space.
The mass range of 10 Kg to 12 Kg is a range property definition within the mass property space.

description.P: The Independent_property_definition UoF also specifies any tensor symmetries for an independent property definition.
